title: Bridging Cognitive Aging in Rodents to Man Using fMRI in Amnestic MCI
description_brief: This research is being done to find out if daily use of the drug levetiracetam can improve memory function in individuals with memory problems like those associated with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) and Alzheimer's disease (AD).
description_detailed:
Increasing research is focused on conditions that precede the clinical diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease (AD) in order to detect patients at risk for early intervention. One such condition is mild cognitive impairment (MCI). Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) studies in this group of patients have reported increased activation in the Medial Temporal Lobe (MTL) during performance of memory tasks. The functional significance of increased activation is unclear. One possibility is that greater activity reflects the increased effort needed in order to maintain performance, and as such would be a compensatory response. An alternative possibility is that increased activation reflects aberrant physiology related to the disease process itself and as such would be a sign of greater underlying disease severity and would interfere with brain function.

Data in animal models suggest the possibility that low dose levetiracetam (well-tolerated anti-convulsant) treatment may reduce the observed hyperactivity and improve memory performance among individuals with MCI. The investigators are therefore conducting a within-subjects trial of 8 weeks duration, involving 144 subjects and low dose treatment with levetiracetam. During the course of the study, each subject may receive both drug and placebo for two weeks, with the order of administering those treatments counterbalanced. Cognitive testing and fMRI imaging will be obtained after 2-weeks on drug/placebo. The overall goal of the study is to determine if treatment of MCI subjects with low dose levetiracetam reduces hyperactivity within the MTL and improves memory performance.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: Data for the 125mg BID treatment cohort was collected first. Analysis showed no effects of treatment order. As a result, data was collapsed and analyzed irrespective of order across all doses. All subsequent data analyses are thus provided collapsed across treatment orders in all reporting on this study, including the results reported here.

outcomeMeasures.title: Brain Activity in the Dentate Gyrus / CA3 Subregion of the Hippocampus Measured With Blood Oxygenation Level Dependent (BOLD) Functional MRI
outcomeMeasures.description: Measurement of average brain activity in the dentate gyrus / CA3 subregion of the hippocampus measured with BOLD functional MRI in patients with mild cognitive impairment on placebo and on drug compared to average brain activity in this brain area in control subjects.

outcomeMeasures.title: Behavioral Performance as Assessed in the Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) Memory Task
outcomeMeasures.description: Mnemonic similarity task which assesses long term memory function. Scale ranges from 0-100 with higher scores indicating better memory performance.

drug: levetiracetam (antiepileptic drug; binds SV2A; studied at low doses to reduce hippocampal hyperactivity and improve memory)
placebo: Not specified in the short description
explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is levetiracetam given daily to improve memory in people with MCI/AD. The goal described is to improve memory function (symptomatic cognitive improvement) rather than to directly target core AD pathology such as amyloid or tau. citeturn0search5turn0search2.

Act: Key evidence about the drug — levetiracetam is an antiepileptic that binds the synaptic vesicle protein SV2A and has been repurposed in several studies at low doses to reduce hippocampal hyperactivity and improve episodic memory in aMCI/AD. Representative sources: Bakker et al. (reduction of hippocampal hyperactivity and improved cognition in aMCI), randomized LEV-AD trial, and mechanistic work showing SV2A is the binding site of levetiracetam. citeturn0search5turn0search2turn0search1.

Act (trial mapping): The title and description (Bridging Cognitive Aging... fMRI in Amnestic MCI) match prior studies using low-dose levetiracetam to normalize hippocampal overactivity and test for memory improvement using fMRI and cognitive outcomes — a symptomatic, cognition-targeting approach rather than disease-modifying therapy against amyloid/tau. citeturn0search5turn0search3.

Reflect: Classification as a 'cognitive enhancer' fits the provided category definitions because levetiracetam here is used to improve cognitive function by modulating neural activity (hippocampal hyperexcitability), not to target AD molecular pathology. Multiple clinical proofs-of-concept and trials examine this symptomatic/cognitive effect (including crossover and randomized trials), supporting this assignment. citeturn0search5turn0search2turn0search4.

- Bakker A, et al., Reduction of hippocampal hyperactivity improves cognition in amnestic mild cognitive impairment (proof-of-concept showing low-dose levetiracetam reduced DG/CA3 overactivation and improved task memory). citeturn0search5.
- LEV-AD randomized clinical trial (phase 2a) testing levetiracetam in AD; showed some cognitive benefit in prespecified subgroups (patients with epileptiform activity). citeturn0search2.
- Mechanistic paper: SV2A is the binding site for levetiracetam (explains molecular target but not disease pathology). citeturn0search1.

- Protocols and proof-of-concept trials extending this approach to MCI/PD and AD (use of low-dose levetiracetam to reduce hippocampal hyperactivity measured with fMRI/EEG). citeturn0search3turn0search6.

Notes / ambiguity: The description does not state whether the trial is placebo-controlled, dose, or duration; many published levetiracetam cognition studies used low doses and crossover/placebo designs but the provided text only specifies daily use to improve memory. If you want, I can search for the exact trial registration (by title/PI) to extract trial design details (dose, placebo, endpoints).
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial uses low-dose levetiracetam to reduce hippocampal hyperactivity and improve memory (a symptomatic/cognitive-enhancing approach). Levetiracetam’s known molecular binding site is the synaptic vesicle protein SV2A, and its effects act on synaptic vesicle function and neuronal excitability rather than directly on amyloid or tau pathology. citeturn1search7turn0search0

Act: Key extracted details — drug: levetiracetam; molecular target: SV2A (synaptic vesicle glycoprotein 2A); proposed mechanism in this trial: normalize hippocampal overactivity to improve cognition (hippocampal/ synaptic modulation). Representative sources: Bakker et al. (reduction of hippocampal hyperactivity and improved memory in aMCI), mechanistic SV2A binding studies, and clinical LEV-AD trial examining cognitive effects. citeturn1search7turn0search0turn0search1

Reflect: Classification as 'Synaptic Plasticity/Neuroprotection' fits CADRO because the intervention targets synaptic function (SV2A-mediated vesicle regulation and neuronal excitability) to produce symptomatic cognitive benefit and possible neuroprotective effects, rather than targeting core molecular AD pathologies (amyloid/tau). Additional supporting mechanistic/review sources are provided below. citeturn0search5turn0search8
- Lynch et al., identification of SV2A as the levetiracetam binding site. citeturn0search0
- Bakker et al., Reduction of Hippocampal Hyperactivity Improves Cognition in Amnestic MCI (Neuron, 2012). citeturn1search7
- LEV-AD randomized clinical trial (effect of levetiracetam on cognition in AD). citeturn0search1
- Levetiracetam reverses synaptic deficits produced by overexpression of SV2A (mechanistic synaptic work). citeturn0search5
- Review of levetiracetam mechanisms summarizing SV2A binding and synaptic effects. citeturn0search8
